Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: A rarely used machine shows an intermittent glitch during a slow production period.
Story: It’s Saturday afternoon, and my phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “How are you? Haven’t heard from you this week.” I know she worries, especially since I moved out, and I promised I’d check in more often. I start typing a reply, but just then, my work phone rings. The plant manager’s voice is tense—one of the old packaging machines is acting up, and no one else can figure it out. Even though it’s a slow weekend, he wants it fixed before Monday. I glance at the half-written text to Mom, guilt prickling in my chest. She just wants to know I’m okay, to feel connected. But the manager expects me to drop everything and get the machine running, no matter the hour. I stare at both phones, feeling pulled in two directions—one by the quiet, persistent love of my family, the other by the urgent, unspoken demand to keep the factory moving. My fingers hover, uncertain, as I wrestle with which part of me should answer first.
